Question
========
A particle initially moving with a velocity of 2 m/s in the $x$-direction experiences a constant acceleration of $1 \,\mathsf{m/s^2}$ in the $x$-direction and $-2 \,\mathsf{m/s^2}$ in the $y$-direction. What are the velocity components of the particle after 4 s?

Answerlist
----------
* $v_x = 6 \,\mathsf{m/s}, v_y = -8 \,\mathsf{m/s}$
* $v_x = -6 \,\mathsf{m/s}, v_y = 4 \,\mathsf{m/s}$
* $v_x = 3 \,\mathsf{m/s}, v_y = -2 \,\mathsf{m/s}$
* $v_x = 4 \,\mathsf{m/s}, v_y = -8 \,\mathsf{m/s}$

Solution
========
The velocities can be calculated separately.

$$v_x = 2 \,\mathsf{m/s} + (1 \,\mathsf{m/s^2})(4 \,\mathsf{s}) = 6 \,\mathsf{m/s}$$
$$v_y = 0 \,\mathsf{m/s} + (-2 \,\mathsf{m/s^2})(4 \,\mathsf{s}) = 8 \,\mathsf{m/s}$$
